ygData.subject: (GDLOTT.EXE VIRUS WARNING!!) Fwd: Congratulations !
ygData.msgSnippet: It is suggested that you do not run programs that you recieve via e-mail unless you are EXPECTING TO RECIEVE it and know EXACTLY what it is supposed to do.
ygData.rawEmail:
X-Digest-Num: 64
Message-ID: <17248.64.167.959279670@...>
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2000 13:56:27 -0500
From: Cookie <cookie@...>
Subject: (GDLOTT.EXE VIRUS WARNING!!) Fwd: Congratulations !

It is suggested that "you do not run programs that you recieve via e-mail
unless you are EXPECTING TO RECIEVE it and know EXACTLY what it is supposed
to do."

Sounds like a virus to me.

So, curious, I took a peek at the hexdump of the program... it calls
kernel32.dll, user32.dll, gdi32.dll, comctl32.dll ... but masks those
contents when viewed with QuickView.

Sounds like a virus to me again.

There are _NO_ textstrings in the program at all. I don't know about you,
but trying to "ask qustions" without WRITING anything is rather difficult.
Just to make sure, I checked glad.exe, and a handful of others..

It's possible that the text is encrypted/encoded somehow, but that sounds
suspicious anyways.. why would you bother for something like this? It makes
no sense from a programmer's perspective.

Virus again.

If you don't think it's a virus and you run it and it ISN'T a virus, then
you're acknowledging that you want to defraud gamesdomain.com anyways...
which is illegal anyways.

Therefore, it is in _EVERYONES BEST INTREST_ to delete the file gdlott.exe
from your hard drive.

Thank you for your time, and i hope "-Tevildo. <tevildo@...>" has a
good explanation for this. :P
-Cookie

>Can anyone make use of this? Of course, I'm not suggesting that anyone 
>actually misuse this forward in violation of the original intent... Consider 
>it "for research purposes only".
>
